questions.text: A one-year-old boy presents with lethargy, poor muscle tone, and developmental delays. Blood tests reveal elevated levels of glycine. The physician suspects a defect in the glycine cleavage system. Which of the following metabolites, if found LOW, would support the diagnosis of a defective glycine cleavage system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) N5,N10 methylene tetrahydrofolate

 

Explanation:

 

  • The glycine cleavage system directly produces N5,N10-methylene tetrahydrofolate when it breaks down glycine.
  • A defect in this system would lead to a decreased production of this metabolite.

 

Glycine Cleavage System

Location
  • Liver mitochondria

Function
  • Splits glycine into carbon dioxide, and ammonia, and forms N⁵, N¹⁰-methylenetetrahydrofolate (THFA).

Glycine Cleavage Complex
  • Composed of three enzymes and an H-protein.

Subunits
  • T: Tetrahydrofolate-dependent aminotransferase
  • P: Pyridoxal phosphate-dependent glycine decarboxylase
  • L: Lipoamide-dependent dehydrogenase
  • H: Hydrogen or electron transport system

Co-enzymes
  • Tetrahydrofolate (THF)
  • Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP)
  • Lipoamide

Reaction Mechanism
  • Glycine is broken down into CO₂, NH₄⁺, and a methylene group (–CH₂–).
  • The methylene group is transferred to THF, forming N⁵,N¹⁰-methylenetetrahydrofolate.

Reaction

Glycine + H₄-folate + NAD⁺ → CO₂ + NH₃ + 5,10-CH₂-H₄-folate + NADH + H⁺

Major Catabolic Pathway
  • The glycine cleavage system is the major catabolic route for glycine.

Associated Disorders
  • Nonketotic Hyperglycinemia: Accumulation of glycine in body tissues and CNS.
  • Primary Hyperoxaluria: Failure to break down glyoxylate leads to oxalate formation, kidney stones, and possible renal failure or hypertension.
  • Glycinuria: A defect in kidney reabsorption causes excessive glycine in urine.

 

 

 

Serine levels might even increase as the body tries to compensate for the glycine deficiency. (Option A)

 

A defective glycine cleavage system is unlikely to directly impact threonine levels. (Option C)

 

Succinyl CoA is involved in heme synthesis; defects in glycine breakdown wouldn't impact succinyl CoA levels. (Option D)

questions.text: A patient with a urea cycle disorder is being evaluated. Which urea cycle intermediate serves as the link between the urea cycle and the TCA cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fumarate

 

Explanation:

  • Argininosuccinate lyase cleaves argininosuccinate to arginine and fumarate.
  • Fumarate is converted to malate and then to oxaloacetate in the TCA cycle, which is transaminated to aspartate.
  • This links the urea cycle with the TCA cycle.
  • The reaction can be summarised as Citrulline + aspartate → Arginine + fumarate.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with poor feeding, lethargy, and vomiting. Lab results show elevated ammonia levels, increased glutamine and increased orotic acid in the blood, with no evidence of megaloblastic anaemia. Which enzyme deficiency is likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC)

 

Explanation:

  • Hyperammonemia type 2 is an X-linked deficiency caused by a defect in ornithine transcarbamoylase (this reaction occurs in mitochondria), which forms citrulline in the Krebs cycle.
  • Mothers with this condition may have hyperammonemia and avoid high-protein foods.
  • Elevated blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine glutamine levels are due to increased glutamine synthesis in response to high ammonia levels.
  • Orotic aciduria- Due to the channelling of carbamoyl phosphate into pyrimidine synthesis.

questions.text: Which enzyme in the histidine catabolism pathway facilitates incorporating the formimino group into the one-carbon pool, forming N5-formimino tetrahydrofolate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Glutamate Formimino transferase

Explanation:

Glutamate Formimino transferase catalyzes the transfer of the formimino group from formiminoglutamate (FIGLU) to THFA, forming N5-formimino THFA​.

Catabolism of Histidine to α-ketoglutarate:

 

 

Reaction

Substrate

Enzyme

Product

1.

Histidine

Histidase (Option A)

Urocanate

2.

Urocanate

Urocanase (Option B)

Imidazole propionic acid

3.

Imidazole propionic acid

Hydrolase

Formiminoglutamate (FIGLU)

4.

FIGLU

Glutamate Formimino transferase (Option C)

L-Glutamate

5.

Glutamate

Glutamate dehydrogenase (Option D)

α-Ketoglutarate

 

Histidine to α-Ketoglutarate Pathway: Role of Tetrahydrofolate (THF)

  • Histidine is metabolised to α-ketoglutarate, which subsequently enters the TCA cycle.

 

Role of Tetrahydrofolate (THF):

  • Histidine is broken down into formiminoglutamate (FIGLU).
  • THF plays a critical role in converting FIGLU to glutamate.
  • THF Function: THF accepts the formimino group (FIG) from FIGLU to become 5-formimino tetrahydrofolate (FITHFA).
  • As a result of losing formimino group (FIG), FIGLU becomes glutamate.

 

Folate Deficiency Consequences:

  • Without sufficient THF, FIGLU cannot transfer its formimino group.
  • FIGLU builds up and is excreted in urine, especially after a histidine load.


Histidine Load Test: Used to diagnose folate deficiency by detecting elevated levels of FIGLU in urine after a histidine load.

questions.text: In the kynurenine pathway of tryptophan catabolism, which of the following compounds directly contributes to the formation of N10-formyl tetrahydrofolate in the one-carbon pool?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Formyl kynurenine

Explanation:

  • Formyl kynurenine is a key intermediate in the kynurenine pathway.
  • It is directly involved in transferring a formyl group, which leads to the production of N10-formyl THFA, an important one-carbon donor in nucleotide biosynthesis​.

 

 

 

 

 

Tryptophan Catabolism and One-Carbon Pool Contributions

Compound

Role in Tryptophan Catabolism

Contribution

Formylkynurenine (Option A)

Intermediate; releases formate for N10-formyl THFA

Directly contributes to the formation of N10-formyl THFA

Kynurenine

(Option B)

Intermediate; precursor for other metabolites

Participates in the synthesis of other metabolites like quinolinic acid and nicotinic acid​.

3- Hydroxy kynurenine (Option C)

Intermediate; precursor for other metabolites

The product formed from formate derived from formylkynurenine

THFA

(Option D)

Carrier of one-carbon units

Not directly derived from tryptophan catabolism

questions.text: A 62-year-old female patient presents with fatigue, pallor, and glossitis. Laboratory tests indicate macrocytic anaemia, and elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels. Given these findings, what is the most likely metabolic pathway disrupted by this patient's condition, leading to the observed anaemia?

choices.text: Reduction of folic acid to dihydrofolate
Deamination of histidine to formimino glutamate

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Conversion of homocysteine to methionine

Explanation:

  • Macrocytic anaemia, elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels are consistent with Vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Conversion of homocysteine to methionine is disrupted in vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Vitamin B12 is a cofactor for methionine synthase, the enzyme responsible for converting homocysteine to methionine.
  • This, in turn, forms S-adenosylmethionine, which is necessary for the synthesis of nitrogenous bases in DNA and RNA.
  • In the absence of vitamin B12, the N5-methyltetrahydrofolate (N5-methyl THF) is trapped, leading to a functional folate deficiency and, consequently, macrocytic anaemia​.
  • This "methyl folate trap" hypothesis explains why folate becomes metabolically inactive.

Folate Trap:

 

Reduction of folic acid to dihydrofolate (Option B) is catalyzed by dihydrofolate reductase and is unrelated to the vitamin B12-dependent processes.

  • It is involved in the conversion of folic acid (the synthetic form) into its active form.
     

Deamination of histidine to formimino glutamate (Option C) is related to folate metabolism but is more directly associated with diagnosing folate deficiency by the presence of FIGLU in the urine.
 

Conversion of Phenylalanine to Tyrosine (Option D) is catalyzed by Phenylalanine hydroxylase, which does not require vitamin B12 as a cofactor.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding one-carbon derivatives of tetrahydrofolic acid (THFA) and their associated enzymes and reactions is incorrect?

choices.text: N5-methyl-THFA carries the methyl group for converting homocysteine to methionine.
N5N10-methylene-THFA is required to synthesise thymidylate (dTMP) from deoxyuridylate (dUMP).
N10-formyl-THFA transfers formyl groups in pyrimidine synthesis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) N10-formyl-THFA transfers formyl groups in pyrimidine synthesis.

Explanation:

N10-formyl-THFA transfers formyl groups in purine synthesis, forming C2 of the purine ring.

One-Carbon Compounds:

One-Carbon Derivatives of THFA

Description

Source

Utilization

N5-formyl-THFA and N10-formyl-THFA

(Option D)

  

Carry a formyl group (-CHO)

  

Tryptophan
  • Synthesis of purine nucleotides, forming C2 of the purine ring.

N5-formimino-THFA (Option A)

Carries a formimino group (-CH=NH)

  

Histidine via FIGLU
  • Involved in the conversion of formiminoglutamate (FIGLU) to glutamate, a step in histidine catabolism; Enzyme: Formiminoglutamate hydrolase

N10-hydroxymethyl-THFA

Carries a hydroxymethyl group (-CH2OH)

  

Choline and betaine

  
 

N5, N10-methylene-THFA (Option C)

  

Carries a methylene group (-CH2-)

  

Serine via serine hydroxymethyl transferase, glycine
  • Glycine synthesis (conversion of serine to glycine),
  • Thymidine synthesis (conversion of dUMP to dTMP); Enzyme: Thymidylate synthase
 

N5-methyl-THFA

(Option B)

  

Carries a methyl group (-CH3)

  

All one-carbon units ultimately form N5-methyl-THFA.
  • Methionine synthesis (conversion of homocysteine to methionine); Enzyme: Methionine synthase
  • Precursor for S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) for various transmethylation reactions.

questions.text: In the following figure, identify the sources of the marked components.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) a-aspartate, b-glycine

 

Explanation:

  • The above-marked nitrogen atom is derived from the amino acid aspartate and the carbon atoms from glycine.
  • The major site is the liver.
  • Requires three amino acids - Glycine, Aspartate, Glutamine and the cofactor N10-formyl tetrahydrofolate (N10- formyl THF) for purine ring formation.

 

 

 

  • The sources of each atom in a purine were found by feeding isotopic precursors of uric acid to pigeons.
    • The C-2 atom is from formyl THF
    • The C-8 atom is from N5N10 methenyl THF
    • The C-6 atom is from respiratory CO2.
    • N1 is from aspartate
    • N3 and N9 are from Glutamine
    • C4, C5 and N7 are from Glycine
  • Methionine and alanine have no relation to purine synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is caused by the deficiency of the enzyme 𝛿 ALA synthase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) X linked sideroblastic anaemia

 

Explanation:

  • The deficiency of ALA synthase causes X-linked sideroblastic anaemia.
  • Heme synthesis occurs in the bone marrow (85%) and hepatocytes.
  • It starts with the condensation of succinyl-CoA and glycine.
  • First step: Reaction takes place in mitochondria.
  • Substrates used: Glycine.
  • Glycine reacts with succinyl CoA (intermediate of the citric acid cycle) in the presence of 𝛿 ALAsynthase to form dALA.
  • It is a decarboxylation reaction.
  • Coenzyme: Pyridoxal phosphate.
  • Prerequisite: Glycine should enter into mitochondria.
  • Transporter: SLC25A38
     

Enzyme Defect

Name of the Disorder

ALA synthase II

X linked sideroblastic anaemia (Option B)

ALA Dehydratase

ALA dehydratase deficient porphyria (ADP)

Porphobilinogen deaminase (Hydroxymethylbilane synthase)

Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) (Option C)

Uroporphyrinogen III synthase

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (most severe) (Option D)

Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase defect

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) (Option A)

Coproporphyrinogen oxidase

Hereditary coproporphyria

Protoporphyrinogen oxidase

Variegate porphyria

Ferrochelatase

Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP)

questions.text: Based on the image given below, what are the sites at which the marked steps of creatinine synthesis occur?

choices.text: a- brain, b- liver, c- kidney
a- kidney, b- liver, c- muscle
a- liver, b- kidney, c- muscle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) a- kidney, b- liver, c- muscle

 

Explanation:

Creatinine synthesis requires the enzyme creatine kinase which is found in the liver, kidney and muscle.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Steps

 

Enzyme

 

Site

1.

The Amidino group of arginine is transferred to glycine to form guanidinoacetic acid.

Amidotransferase

Kidney (a) and pancreas

2.

Guanidoacetic acid is Methylated by S-adenosyl methionine to form creatine.

Methyl transferase

Liver (b)

3.

Creatine is phosphorylated to creatine phosphate.

Creatine kinase

Muscle, brain and liver.

4.

Creatine phosphate may be converted to its anhydride, creatinine

Non- enzymatic

Muscle (c)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a known use of glycine in humans?

choices.text: Precursor for metabolites like creatine, glutathione, and heme.
Enhances the quality of sleep and supports neurological functions.
Inhibits synthesis of bile acid, reducing lipid absorption.
Provide structural integrity for collagen structure.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inhibits bile acid synthesis, reducing lipid absorption.

 

Explanation:

 

Uses of Glycine

1) Metabolic Functions:
  • Precursor for metabolites such as creatine, glutathione, heme, purines, and porphyrins. (Option A)
  • Vital for protein synthesis.
  • Plays a crucial role in collagen structure by occupying every third position in the collagen triple helix. (Option D)

2) Health and Disease Prevention:
  • Dietary supplementation can prevent or treat metabolic disorders in patients with cardiovascular diseases, inflammatory diseases, obesity, cancers, and diabetes.
  • Supports overall health, growth, and well-being in humans.

3) Neurological and Sleep Benefits:
  • Acts as a neurotransmitter in the central nervous system, influencing food intake, behaviour, and body homeostasis.
  • Enhances sleep quality and neurological functions. (Option B)

4) Immune Function:
  • Regulates immune responses by altering intracellular calcium levels.
  • Modulates the production of superoxide and cytokines.

5) Digestive Health:
  • Facilitates the conjugation of bile acids.
  • Aid in the absorption and digestion of lipid-soluble vitamins and lipids. (Option C)

questions.text: The glycine cleavage system in the body produces CO2, ammonia and a one-carbon molecule. Which of the following is a subunit in the system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tetrahydrofolate-dependent aminomethyltransferase (THFAAMT)

 

Explanation:

  • The subunit of the glycine cleavage system here is THFAAMT, and the others are the coenzymes that participate in the system.
  • The glycine cleavage system takes place in the liver mitochondria.

 

 

 

 

  • In this system, the simple amino acid glycine is split into ammonia and CO2, and the remaining methylene group (–CH2–) is transferred by Tetrahydrofolate and converted into N5N10 methylene tetrahydrofolate.

 

Subunits of the glycine cleavage system

Co-enzymes of glycine cleavage system

Tetrahydrofolate dependant aminotransferase (THFAAMT) (Option C)

THF (Option A)

Pyridoxal phosphate-dependant (PLP) glycine decarboxylase

Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) (Option D)

Lipoamide dependent dehydrogenase

Lipoamide (Option B)

Hydrogen or electron transport system

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presented with lethargy, vomiting, and irritability. Blood tests revealed elevated ammonia levels. The infant was diagnosed with a urea cycle disorder. Which of the following medications, acting as ammonia-scavenging agents, would be most effective in reducing the infant's blood ammonia levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Phenylacetate

 

Explanation:

 

Reducing blood ammonia levels:

 

  • Ammonia-Scavenging Agent:
    • Sodium benzoate:
      • It reacts with glycine in the liver to form hippuric acid, which is then excreted in the urine, reducing the availability of glycine.
      • Reducing the availability of glycine shifts the equilibrium to favour glycine formation.
      • Ammonia is used to produce glycine, therefore reducing blood ammonia levels.
    • Phenylacetate:
      • Conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine (PGA), which is then excreted in the urine, depleting glutamine levels.
      • Glutamate production from ammonia and alpha-ketoglutarate increases to compensate for depletion.
      • Each molecule of phenyl acetate utilises two molecules of ammonia: one for the initial glutamine conjugation and one for subsequent glutamate-to-glutamine conversion.
      • Phenylbutyrate is a prodrug metabolised into phenylacetate.
      • This binds with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine and is excreted by the kidneys, removing excess nitrogen and ammonia.
  • Protein degradation:
    • Adequate caloric intake can help prevent protein breakdown and, subsequently, ammonia production.
  • Urease-producing microorganisms: Certain bacteria in the gut produce urease, an enzyme that breaks down urea into ammonia. To prevent this,
    • Low-dose neomycin: Helps suppress the growth of urease-producing bacteria. (Option D)
    • Lactulose: Converts ammonia into ammonium ions, which cannot be easily absorbed, thus reducing the amount of ammonia. (Option C)

 

N-acetyl glutamate is used to treat hyperammonemia but does not directly scavenge ammonia. (Option B)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue and abdominal discomfort. Blood tests reveal elevated levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST). The physician suspects liver disease. Which of the following statements best describes the role of transamination reactions in amino acid metabolism?

choices.text: Transfer an amino group to one keto acid, producing new amino and keto acids.
Specific to lysine, threonine, and proline.
Elevated AST and ALT indicate myocardial infarction.
Occur exclusively in the liver mitochondria.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Transfer an amino group to one keto acid, producing new amino and keto acids.

 

Explanation:

Transamination reactions transfer an amino group from an amino acid to a keto acid, catalysed by aminotransferases with Pyridoxal Phosphate (PLP) as a coenzyme.
 

Transamination Process
  • Transfer of an α-amino group from an amino acid to one keto acid, producing a new α-keto acid and a new amino acid. (Option A)
  • The first step is the catabolism of most amino acids.
  • All amino acids, except Proline, hydroxyproline, threonine, and lysine, participate in transamination. (Option B)

Biological Importance
  • Amino Acid Interconversion: Maintains balance of non-essential amino acids by transferring amino groups to synthesise needed amino acids.
  • Ammonia Disposal: Detoxifies ammonia by funnelling amino groups into glutamate, which is deaminated in the liver for excretion.

Glutamate's Role
  • α-Ketoglutarate: Acts as an acceptor of amino groups from most amino acids, converting to glutamate.
  • Transamination occurs in the cytoplasm; the amino group is transported to the liver as glutamate. (Option D)
  • Oxidative Deamination: Glutamate undergoes rapid oxidative deamination in the mitochondria to form α-ketoglutarate, which can accept another amino group.

Enzymes
  • Aminotransferases (Transaminases): Catalyse the transfer of amino groups between carbon skeletons. They are not coenzymes. (Option C)
  • Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT): Transfers amino group from alanine to α-ketoglutarate, forming pyruvate and glutamate.
  • Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST): Transfers amino groups from glutamate to oxaloacetate, forming aspartate used in the urea cycle.

Coenzyme
  • Pyridoxal Phosphate (PLP): Required by all aminotransferases, derived from vitamin B6.

Reversibility
  • Transamination reactions are reversible, with equilibrium constants near 1.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a source of glycine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lysine

 

Explanation:

Serine, Threonine and Alanine are sources of Glycine, whereas Lysine is not.

 

Glycine

  • Simple, non-essential amino acid.
  • Acts as a precursor for metabolites like creatine, glutathione, heme, purines, and porphyrins.
  • Vital for protein synthesis, collagen structure, neurotransmission, immune response, and lipid digestion.

 

Sources of Glycine:

 

  1. Serine: Converted to glycine via serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SMT), present in mitochondria and cytoplasm. (Option A)
  2. Threonine: Converted to glycine by threonine aldolase. (Option B)
  3. Choline: Converted to glycine via sarcosine and betaine pathways.
  4. Glycine Synthase:
  • Synthesises glycine from CO₂, NH₄⁺, and a one-carbon unit.
  • This multi-enzyme complex requires NAD, lipoamide, tetrahydrofolic acid, and pyridoxal phosphate.
  • This is a reversal of the glycine cleavage system.
  • Glycine Aminotransferase: Catalyses glycine synthesis from glyoxylate and glutamate or alanine. (Option C)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with microcytic anaemia is found to have a deficiency of a vitamin essential for the rate-limiting step of heme synthesis. Which vitamin is most likely deficient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vitamin B6

 

Explanation:

  • Heme biosynthesis begins in mitochondria with the condensation of succinyl Co-A and glycine.
  • This reaction produces 5'-aminolevulinic acid (ALA), a key heme intermediate.
  • The enzyme aminolevulinic acid synthase (ALAS) requires pyridoxal phosphate (Vitamin B6) to catalyze this step.
  • This reaction is the rate-limiting step in heme synthesis.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy presents with failure to thrive, developmental delay, and intermittent episodes of vomiting and lethargy. The episodes coincide with the introduction of solid foods. Blood tests reveal elevated ammonia levels and high levels of ornithine in blood. Urine analysis shows increased excretion of homocitrulline. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
This child with hyperammonemia triggered after solid food introduction is most likely to have HHH syndrome.

 

Hyperornithinemia-Hyperammonemia-Homocitrullinuria Syndrome

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Defective Gene

ORC1

Defective Protein

Mitochondrial Ornithine Transporter: This transporter moves ornithine into the mitochondria and citrulline out of the mitochondria.

Mechanism
  • Prevents ornithine from entering the mitochondria, which is necessary for the urea cycle.
  • The buildup of ammonia in the blood (hyperammonemia).
  • Ornithine also accumulates in the cytoplasm (hyperornithinemia).
  • Carbamoyl phosphate reacts with lysine to form homocitrulline.

Symptoms
  • Failure to thrive.
  • Developmental delay.
  • Intermittent episodes of vomiting and lethargy (triggered by protein intake).
  • Seizures.
  • Intellectual disability.

Diagnosis
  • Elevated blood ammonia
  • Elevated blood ornithine
  • Elevated urinary homocitrulline.

Treatment
  • Low-protein diet
  • Nitrogen scavenger medications
  • Liver transplant in severe cases.

 

  • Citrullinemia (Option A) leads to the accumulation of citrulline, which would be elevated in blood tests, unlike in this scenario.

 

  • Argininosuccinate aciduria (Option B) causes the characteristic symptom of trichorrhexis nodosa (brittle, easily broken hair), which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

  • Argininemia (Option D) involves hyperammonemia. Compared to other urea cycle disorders, its presentation is typically delayed, appearing around 2 years of age, not at 5 months.

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant with a history of vomiting, irritability, and developmental delay. The onset of symptoms coincided with the introduction of formula feed. Physical examination revealed hepatomegaly and signs of encephalopathy. Blood tests revealed elevated ammonia levels and high glutamine, uracil, and orotic acid concentrations. Citrulline levels were normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type 2 Hyperammonemia

 

Explanation:

The infant's symptoms and laboratory findings with the timing of symptom onset after the introduction of the formula are highly suggestive of Type 2 Hyperammonemia.

 

Feature

Type 1 Hyperammonemia

Type 2 Hyperammonemia

Defective Enzyme

Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I (CPS1)

Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC)

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

X-linked recessive

Mechanism

The inability to synthesize carbamoyl phosphate blocks the urea cycle.

Accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate in the mitochondria, which then spills over into the cytoplasm.

Metabolic Consequences
  • Elevated ammonia and glutamate
  • Normal orotic acid and uracil
  • Low citrulline. (Option A)
  • Elevated ammonia, glutamate, and glutamine.
  • High uracil and orotic acid (excess carbamoyl phosphate enters pyrimidine synthesis).
  • Normal citrulline.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms coincide with increased protein intake.
  • CNS: Lethargy, drowsiness, coma, Convulsions, vomiting, respiratory stimulation, hyperventilation.
  • Similar to Type 1.
  • Hepatomegaly.


 

Citrullinemia and Argininosuccinate aciduria (Option C and D) would result in elevated citrulline levels, contradicting the normal citrulline finding in this scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about carbamoyl phosphate synthetases is correct?

choices.text: CPS-I is activated by PRPP, and CPS-II is inhibited by UTP.
CPS-I is located in cytosol, and CPS-II in mitochondria.
CPS-I is involved in urea cycle, and CPS-II in pyrimidine synthesis.
Source of nitrogen for CPS-I is glutamine, and CPS-II is ammonia.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CPS-I is involved in the urea cycle and CPS-II in pyrimidine synthesis.

 

Explanation:

CPS-I is involved in the urea cycle, whereas CPS-II is involved in pyrimidine synthesis.

 

Aspect

Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase-I (CPS-I)

Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase-II (CPS-II)

Site (Option B)

Mitochondria

Cytosol

Pathway involved (Option C)

Urea cycle

Pyrimidine synthesis

Source of Nitrogen (Option D)

Ammonia

𝛾-Amide group of glutamine

Positive effector (Option A)

N-acetyl glutamate

Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP)

Inhibitor

Nil

Uridine triphosphate(UTP)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the rate-limiting step of the urea cycle?

choices.text: It involves the formation of citrulline from ornithine.
It is catalysed by carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I).
It is regulated by argininosuccinate synthetase.
It is controlled by the enzyme argininosuccinate lyase.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is catalysed by carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I).

 

Explanation:

  • The carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I) reaction is the rate-limiting step in the urea cycle.
  • The urea cycle is a cycle of biochemical reactions that produce urea from ammonia.
  • It is also known as the Krebs-Henseleit urea cycle or the Ornithine cycle.
  • It starts in the mitochondria of hepatocytes and ends in the cytoplasm.

 

                     

 

Reactions in the Urea Cycle

Step

Reaction Details

Enzyme Involved and Location

Key Points

Carbamoyl Phosphate Formation
  • Formation of carbamoyl phosphate from ammonia and CO₂ using ATP.
  • Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I (CPS I)
 
  • Mitochondria
  • The rate-limiting step of the urea cycle.
  • Irreversible and allosterically regulated by N-acetyl glutamate (NAG).

Citrulline Formation (Option A)
  • Transfer of carbamoyl phosphate to ornithine to form citrulline.
  • Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC)
     
  • Mitochondria
  • Citrulline moves from mitochondria to cytosol for further processing in the urea cycle.

Argininosuccinate Formation (Option C)
  • Citrulline combines with aspartate to form argininosuccinate.
  • Argininosuccinate Synthetase
 
  • Cytoplasm
  • Requires ATP.
  • Links the urea cycle with the TCA cycle via aspartate.

Argininosuccinate Cleavage (Option D)
  • Cleavage of argininosuccinate into arginine and fumarate.
  • Argininosuccinate Lyase
 
  • Cytoplasm
  • Fumarate enters the TCA cycle, providing a connection between the urea cycle and other metabolic pathways.

Arginine Cleavage to Ornithine and Urea
  • Hydrolysis of arginine to produce ornithine and urea.
  • Arginase
 
  • Cytoplasm
  • Ornithine is recycled back into the urea cycle.
  • Urea is excreted by the kidneys, with some urea also entering the intestine.

Fate of Urea
  • Urea is transported to the kidneys, filtered, and excreted in urine.
  • Kidneys/ Intestine
  • Urea excretion is the final step, removing excess nitrogen from the body.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ammonia transport is correct?

choices.text: Glutamine moves ammonia from liver to brain.
Alanine transports ammonia from liver to muscles.
Glutamine and alanine transport ammonia to the liver.
Alanine does not participate in ammonia transport.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Glutamine and alanine transport ammonia to the liver.

 

Explanation:

Ammonia is transported in a non-toxic form in the circulation as glutamine or alanine.

  • Glutamine is formed from glutamate and ammonia by glutamine synthetase, primarily in skeletal muscle, liver, and CNS. Glutamine transports ammonia from the brain and intestine to the liver. (Option A)
  • Glutamine is transported in the blood to the liver, where it is cleaved by glutaminase to glutamate and ammonia.
  • The glutamate is oxidatively deaminated to ammonia and α-ketoglutarate by glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH), and the ammonia is converted to urea.
  • Alanine is the transport form of ammonia from muscle to the liver. (Option B)
  • Alanine transports ammonia to the liver via the glucose-alanine cycle. (Option D)
  • Alanine is transported in the blood to the liver, where it is transaminated by alanine transaminase(ALT) to pyruvate. The pyruvate is used to synthesise glucose, which can enter the blood and be used by muscles. The glutamate product of ALT can be deaminated by GDH, generating ammonia.
  • Thus, both alanine and glutamine carry ammonia to the liver.

 

Transporter

Formation Process

Source

Destination

Mechanism/Role

Glutamine

Formed from glutamate and ammonia by glutamine synthetase.

Skeletal muscle, liver, CNS

Liver, kidneys
  • Transports ammonia from the brain and intestine to the liver. In the liver, glutamine is cleaved by glutaminase to release ammonia and glutamate.
  • Glutamate is then deaminated by glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH), releasing additional ammonia, which enters the urea cycle for detoxification.

Alanine

Formed from pyruvate and ammonia in muscles during the glucose-alanine cycle.

Muscles

Liver
  • Transports ammonia from muscle to the liver. In the liver, alanine is transaminated by alanine transaminase (ALT) to form pyruvate and glutamate.
  • The pyruvate is used to synthesize glucose, and the glutamate can be deaminated by GDH to release ammonia for the urea cycle.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with elevated ammonia levels presents with confusion and disorientation. Which of the following is not a typical symptom of ammonia toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Muscle rigidity

 

Explanation:

  • Neurotoxic effects of hyperammonemia include tremors, slurred speech, drowsiness, vomiting, cerebral oedema, blurred vision, potential coma and death.
  • Muscle rigidity is not a symptom of ammonia toxicity.

 

Hyperammonemia

  • Occurs in advanced liver disease and certain genetic disorders of amino acid metabolism.
  • It can lead to loss of consciousness, coma, convulsions and may be fatal.
  • This is due to:
  1. Depletion of α-ketoglutarate from the citric acid cycle to form glutamate and glutamine.
  2. Reduced ATP production.
  3. Inhibition of α-ketoglutarate and pyruvate dehydrogenases by elevated ammonia levels.

Neurotoxic effects of hyperammonemia
  • Tremors (Option B)
  • Slurred speech (Option A)
  • Drowsiness
  • Vomiting
  • Cerebral edema
  • Blurred vision (Option D)
  • Potential coma and death

Causes

  • Genetic causes: Urea cycle disorders and organic acidurias
  • Hepatic encephalopathy
  • Cor pulmonale
  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Renal failure

Management
  • Low-protein/high-calorie diet
  • Antibiotics to reduce bacterial load ( ￬ urease-producing bacteria)
  • Lactulose to decrease intestinal ammonia production

questions.text: Which of the following pathways is primarily involved in the detoxification of ammonia in the brain?

choices.text: Conversion of ammonia to urea in neurons
Direct excretion of ammonia through the blood-brain barrier
Conversion of ammonia to glutamine via glutamine synthetase in astrocytes
Storage of ammonia in neurons as glutamate

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Conversion of ammonia to glutamine via glutamine synthetase in astrocytes

 

Explanation:

Glutamine synthetase in astrocytes converts glutamate and ammonia to glutamine, effectively detoxifying ammonia in the brain.

 

Ammonia Management in Neurons:

  • Ammonia can be neurotoxic if accumulated.

Glutamine Synthesis:

  • Produced in neurons as a byproduct of amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter turnover.
  • Ammonia reacts with α-ketoglutarate and NADH to form glutamate, catalyzed by glutamate dehydrogenase.

α-ketoglutarate + NH3​ ​+ NADH → Glutamate + NAD+ + H2​O

  • Glutamate is converted to glutamine by glutamine synthetase, adding another ammonia molecule. Glutamine synthetase is predominantly found in astrocytes.

Glutamate + NH3​ + ATP → Glutamine + ADP + Pi

  • This conversion reduces ammonia toxicity by storing it in a non-toxic form.

 

The fate of glutamine:
Release into the Bloodstream:

  • Glutamine is released into the extracellular space and enters the bloodstream.
  • This transport helps maintain nitrogen balance and prevents ammonia accumulation.

 

Transport to the Liver:

  • Glutamine carries ammonia from the brain to the liver, where it is deaminated to release ammonia.
  • Ammonia enters the urea cycle in the liver for detoxification.

 

Importance of Glutamine in Neuronal Health:

  • Acts as a non-toxic ammonia carrier, preventing neurotoxicity.
  • Serves as a precursor for neurotransmitters like GABA, maintaining neurotransmitter balance.

questions.text: Which of the following reactions is not catalysed by glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH)?

choices.text: Conversion of α-ketoglutarate and ammonia to glutamate
Formation of aspartate from oxaloacetate and ammonia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Formation of aspartate from oxaloacetate and ammonia

 

Explanation:

  • The formation of aspartate from oxaloacetate and ammonia is catalyzed by aspartate transaminase, not GDH.
  • In the liver, ammonia transforms into the less toxic form, urea, using glutamate and the enzyme glutamate dehydrogenase.
     
  • Location: Found exclusively in liver mitochondria.

 

Reactions Catalyzed by Glutamate Dehydrogenase:

  • Oxidative Deamination (Conversion of Glutamate to α-Ketoglutarate)

 

L-Glutamate + NAD+ → α-Ketoglutarate + NH3​ + NADH + H+

 

  • Catalyzed by: GDH (Option A)
  • Coenzyme: NAD⁺
  • Reductive Amination (Synthesis of Glutamate from α-Ketoglutarate)

 

α-Ketoglutarate + NH3​ + NADPH + H+ → L-Glutamate + NADP+

 

  • Catalyzed by: GDH (Option B)
  • Coenzyme: NAD⁺

 

Regulation:

  • Activation: ADP activates GDH.
  • Inhibition: GTP, ATP, and NADH allosterically inhibit GDH.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of amino acids do not undergo transamination reactions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lysine and threonine

 

Explanation:

Lysine and Threonine:

  • These amino acids do not undergo typical transamination.
  • Lysine has an epsilon-amino group that can interfere with the transamination mechanism, and threonine undergoes deamination rather than transamination.
    • Transamination is essential for amino acid catabolism and urea formation.
    • Most amino acids participate in transamination reactions.

 

Exceptions:

Amino Acid

Reason

Proline
  • Has a secondary amino group within its pyrrolidine ring structure.
  • It cannot participate in standard transamination due to its structural characteristics.

Hydroxyproline
  • Derived from proline through post-translational modification; shares the same structural limitation.

Lysine
  • Has an epsilon-amino group in its side chain, which can form Schiff bases, potentially interfering with transamination.

Threonine
  • Loses its α-amino group through deamination rather than transamination.
  • Direct transamination does not occur; instead, it is converted to alpha-ketobutyric acid.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with confusion and lethargy. Blood tests show elevated levels of ammonia, suggesting hyperammonemia. Further tests indicate liver dysfunction. Which of the following best describes the process of oxidative deamination in amino acid metabolism?

choices.text: Removal of an amino group from an amino acid, resulting in the corresponding keto acid and ammonia.
Involves only transamination reactions in the cytoplasm.
Generates ammonia, which is directly excreted by the kidneys.
Predominantly occurs in the liver cytoplasm, producing glutamine.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Removal of an amino group from an amino acid, resulting in the corresponding keto acid and ammonia.

 

Explanation:

  • Oxidative deamination removes the alpha-amino group from an amino acid, producing a keto acid and ammonia.
  • This reaction, catalysed by glutamate dehydrogenase in liver mitochondria, is essential for ammonia detoxification and nitrogen balance.
  • The ammonia formed is detoxified in the form of glutamate.
  • The ammonia generated is processed through the urea cycle for excretion. (Option C)

 

 

Oxidative Deamination:

  • Process: Removes alpha-amino group from an amino acid, producing a keto acid and ammonia.
  • Common Amino Acid: Glutamic acid.
  • Enzyme: Glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH).

 

Transdeamination:

  • Step 1: Transamination (all organs) in cytoplasm forms glutamate. (Option D)
  • Step 2 (Oxidative decarboxylation): In liver mitochondria, GDH removes the amino group from glutamate, producing alpha-ketoglutarate and ammonia. (Option B)
  • Significance: It ensures efficient ammonia disposal, funnelling ammonia into the liver for detoxification via the urea cycle.

 

Minor deamination Pathways:

  • Involve enzymes like L-amino acid oxidase and D-amino acid oxidase.
  • Non-oxidative deamination targets specific amino acids, releasing ammonia.

 

L-Amino Acid Oxidase:

  • It deaminates L-amino acids in the kidney.
  • It generates hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and ammonia as by-products.
  • H2O2, a reactive oxygen species (ROS), is broken down into O2 and H2O by catalase to mitigate damage from ROS.
